snippet: Japan on Saturday will become a nuclear-free nation for the first time in more than four decades, but leaders are worried about power shortages, the economy and widespread opposition against turning the plants back on.
abstract: Last of 50 functional commercial reactors in Japan are set to go offline for routine maintainance, leaving country without nuclear power for the first time in more than four decades; the local resistance to turning plants back on has nation's leaders worrying about power shortages that could drive still more factories to close or move abroad.
lead_paragraph: Japan on Saturday will become a nuclear-free nation for the first time in more than four decades, but leaders are worried about power shortages, the economy and widespread opposition against turning the plants back on.

headline.seo: Japan’s Leaders Fret as Nuclear Shutdown Nears
headline.main: Japan’s Leaders, Pressed by Public, Fret as Nuclear Shutdown Nears
headline.print_headline: Japan’s Leaders, Pressed by Public, Fret as Nuclear Shutdown Nears
